wp:category.wp:category_description: What does the Bible say about technology?

item.title: Technology in Scripture: What does the Bible say about tech?
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
I keep starting and stopping this project, but I am going to take another shot at going through the entire Bible and annotate all the references to technology that I can find.  I hope that by the end of this experiment, I will be able to answer the question, "What does God think of technology?" Before I go through this exercise, I'll need to define technology.  It's really hard to nail down, but for the purposes of this project, let's call it:

technology: the application of knowledge for the creation of tools (knife, computer) or artifacts (clothing, furniture), sometimes toward the facilitation of a process (cooking)

Technology leverages human work to achieve an increased output against a constant amount of work input, which might be measured by time or physical effort.  Often, the creation of a such a tool is built upon many other pre-existing technologies. I will only count "man-made" technologies in this project, discounting anything that could occur in the absence of man.

item.title: Technology in Scripture
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
I keep starting and stopping this project, but I am going to take another shot at going through the entire Bible and annotate all the references to technology that I can find.  I hope that by the end of this experiment, I will be able to answer the question, "What does God think of technology?" Before I go through this exercise, I'll need to define technology.  It's really hard to nail down, but for the purposes of this project, let's call it:

technology: the application of knowledge for the creation of tools (knife, computer) or artifacts (clothing, furniture), sometimes toward the facilitation of a process (cooking)

Technology leverages human work to achieve an increased output against a constant amount of work input, which might be measured by time or physical effort.  Often, the creation of a such a tool is built upon many other pre-existing technologies. I will only count "man-made" technologies in this project, discounting anything that could occur in the absence of man.

Genesis 3:7 — Adam and Eve sew clothes

Then the eyes of both were opened, and they knew that they were naked. And they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves loincloths. (link)
Adam and Eve, having just eaten the fruit of knowledge, find some sort of threading tool and some fiber for thread.  Using fig leaves as the textile material, they create clothes for the first time.  Clothes have been useful for basic decency, protection from the elements, identity, and cultural expression.

item.title: Genesis 3:7 — Adam and Eve sew clothes
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
Then the eyes of both were opened, and they knew that they were naked. And they sewed fig leaves together and made themselves loincloths. (link)
Adam and Eve, having just eaten the fruit of knowledge, find some sort of threading tool and some fiber for thread.  Using fig leaves as the textile material, they create clothes for the first time.  Clothes have been useful for basic decency, protection from the elements, identity, and cultural expression.

item.title: Genesis 3:21 — God makes clothes
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
So God sees Adam and Eve's silly fig leave daisy dukes and says, "Sheez...here let me do that for you."
And the Lord God made for Adam and for his wife garments of skins and clothed them.
It's left as an exercise to the reader to imagine how God "made" these garments.  Did he speak them into existence?  Did he do a Disney Cinderella and get a bunch of animals to sew them together?  In any case, he got some skins (most likely from some animals) and used them to clothe Adam and Eve.

item.title: Genesis 3:24 — God pulls a weapon
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
We may find a pattern in technology in Scripture — it just sort of shows up without much explanation.  Here is the first piece of metalwork that appears in the Bible, pretty early on at that.
He drove out the man, and at the east of the garden of Eden he placed the cherubim and a flaming sword that turned every way to guard the way to the tree of life.
Swords are tools used for stabbing and cutting things (usually people, I think).  To make swords (from what I've seen in movies), you gotta have a strong heat source, fuel, metal, molding casts, hammers and anvils.  I wonder if the angels took care of that stuff or if God just spoke the sword into existence.

item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: About Stacks

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: In the computer science world, the "Hello World" program always the first program written when learning a new language. Once you can get those overly cliched words on the screen, you can do pretty much anything you can think of. TechGlobber.net is going to be the place I keep track of the techie things I'm learning and the thinking behind the decisions I'm making. I am a millenial-generation web and software developer with InsideWork, where I am learning tons about development, design, and a little system administration just for kicks.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: TechGlobber.net is going to be the place I keep track of the techie things I’m learning and the thinking behind the decisions I’m making. I am a millenial-generation web and software developer with InsideWork, where I am learning tons about development, design, and a little system administration just for kicks. I got the idea for this website from Al. I am interested in software design, development, and usability. Any tips would be appreciated.

item.title: Learning Design Principles from God
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
I have lately been growing an interest in design, namely software design and human-computer interface design. At the same time, I have been dreaming up my own software development firm. As I asked myself, what would set my firm apart?, I began to wonder, how would God design software?. I really don't have any answers right now, but I'm thinking that I would have to look at the hard sciences: physics, chemistry, and biology since those disciplines are continually unraveling God's creative genius. Biology may be of special interest because it seems to rest at the same level of software that I am interested in. Physics would be like hardware, chemistry could be the operating system, but biology could be user-level software. Here are some things that I am currently digging into to learn more about design:
  • Design Patterns, The Gang of Four - the definitive reference on time-tested patterns of software design
  • Humanized.com - four really smart guys writing on make computers more usable and humane

item.title: iinnovate Interviews Founder of IDEO
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
David Kelley, on relationships:
Every relationship I have is basically a personal relationship...I don't have business relationships
IDEO is one of the greatest design firms that ever lived, so listen to this podcast if you are interested in design. I don't know how they do it, but iinnovate has been able to get interviews with all these all-stars in technology and design. Here's the link: iinnovate » David Kelley, Founder of IDEO

item.title: Wordpress 2.1: Front Page Appears In Inline Uploading Box in Posting Interface
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: After upgrading to Wordpress 2.1 on FileGlobber, I was having some weird bug in the posting interface where the front page of my site was appearing in an IFRAME where the inline uploader should have been. After digging through some PHP and HTML, I determined that Silas Partners' Flickr Photo-Album Plugin was was incompatible with the new WordPress. They have a new version (released Jan 30 2007) ready for WP 2.1.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Glad to hear you are using the plugin Joe wrote. Feel free to send along any further questions.

item.title: “ImportError: No module named rhn” when upgrading from RHEL3 to RHEL4
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
I was getting this error when trying to run up2date after upgrading Red Hat Enterprise Linux from v3 to v4: > up2date-nox Traceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/sbin/up2date-nox", line 27, in ? from up2date_client import repoDirector File "/usr/share/rhn/up2date_client/repoDirector.py", line 5, in ? import rhnChannel File "/usr/share/rhn/up2date_client/rhnChannel.py", line 10, in ? import up2dateAuth File "/usr/share/rhn/up2date_client/up2dateAuth.py", line 5, in ? import rpcServer File "/usr/share/rhn/up2date_client/rpcServer.py", line 23, in ? from rhn import rpclib ImportError: No module named rhn The solution was to reinstall rhnlib-1.8.2-1.p23.1.noarch.rpm and up2date-4.4.67-4.i386.rpm. Be sure to install those exact versions, since what RHEL4 installs is newer and broken for some reason. Then, when you run up2date -u, up2date will upgrade itself properly. You can get the RPMs through the RHN web interface. References
  1. http://www.archivesat.com/

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
You must manually install up2date, (up2date-gnome) and rhnlib. The package has not been automatically installed because your el3 up2date package has a higher version number than the one on your el4 CD set. Though they have higher version numers, they don't support el4.
use 'rpm -Uvh --oldpackage ' to force a "downgrade" to lower version of the packages from you disk set, that supports el4.
Ingvar
Thank you

item.title: Creation and Computer Science
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: TED is an elite annual conference that brings together the smartest people in the world to gather ideas on how to make the world a better place. I made it sound cheesier than it really is. I just listened to Neil Gershenfeld from MIT talk about fabrication, design, and all sorts of amazing applications. The coolest thing, though, was when he talked about nano-computers that stored information in them similar to how DNA stores information internally. It's fascinating to see man-made things move closer to things God has already designed. Neil Gershenfeld on TED Talks

item.title: iTunes vs. Audacity
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Today I tried using Audacity (an audio editing program) to record a part of a podcast I bought through iTunes. As soon as Audacity opened, my entire Windows audio subsystem started to make ALL my audio sound like demons. I couldn't get a good recording of it. iTunes somehow knows that I am going to rip a song off and it goes through Windows to stop me. After I closed Audacity and restarted iTunes, everything started to work again. Well-played, Apple. But I know DRM is not in your heart, and you will find a way to be free. September 11, 2007 - This appears to happen with Windows Media Player 11 as well.

item.title: Choosing Collaborative Workspace Environment
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
When I was assigned with researching and implementing a collaborative workspace environment, I didn't find much pre-digested material out there. I hope this roundup benefits you. Scenario A group of about 10-15 businessmen are collaborating on a new project. They are all very, very busy people, with average technical aptitude and plenty of business savvy. My assignment: create a place where this group can conduct organized, traceable, collaborative research (no e-mailing PDFs and URLs back and forth). This includes storage for primary sources (PDFs and e-mails), a system for sharing insights or conclusions from those primary sources, and ultimately, the facility to take this research and turn it into the basis for collaborating on the documentation for a business plan. Requirements I had to find a platform that balanced functionality and usability. To make this as user-friendly as possible, I would have to find an e-mail-friendly platform, since the participants were mainly e-mail users. I also wanted to go with a hosted solution to avoid the headache of managing my own installation and servers. After browsing through nine or ten collaborative workspace environments, I narrowed the choices down to four: Basecamp, Central Desktop, Groove, and SocialText. Here are my notes on each of the four (in relation to our needs): 37signals' Basecamp Basecamp is a lightweight web-based collaboration environment that appears to be geared toward small to medium development teams. Pros:
  • Simple, clean interface
Cons:
  • Writeboard, their document system, only supported basic rich text and no table
Choose Basecamp if you nead a clean, lightweight environment to keep tasks organized, but not if you need access to a lot of rich centralized information. Central Desktop Central Desktop is a large, corporate, heavily-marketed, web-based collaborative workspace environment. Pros:
  • Full-featured
  • Full-text search of Word, Excel, Powerpoint, and PDF
  • Can receive files by e-mail and carry archived discussions through e-mail
Cons:
  • Complex interface -- possible resistance to adoption because of high learning curve
Central Desktop is a good choice as long as users can adopt it and someone is available to train them. Groove Groove is a desktop application that creates a virtual group space in which you can collaborate on desktop-based documents (Word, Excel, PowerPoint). It integrates communication features like chat to facilitate collaboration. Functionality is separated into discrete "tools" that the workspace manager adds at his own discretion. Pros:
  • It is geared toward a desktop environment, so users won't have to learn new software; they can use their existing applications
Cons:
  • Expensive! $209 per machine
  • Doesn't appear to safely manage data. If you delete a tool then it's gone forever and the data with it.
  • No document versioning
Groove is nice if your users need to use desktop applications. SocialText SocialText is a web-based wiki environment. Almost all functionality is accomplished by manipulating wiki pages. Pros:
  • Simple interface
Cons:
  • No calendar
  • No proper file repository
Use SocialText if your want to collaborate mainly over text, and you won't be uploading a lot of files. Conclusion Each of these applications has its own niche, and I ended up choosing Central Desktop as the one that fit us the best. One of the biggest factors was the full-text Google search in workspace files and documents. I know that our users will need to use the search tool to find information within the workspace.

item.title: MacBook with 1.5GB Unmatched RAM Crashes
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Picked up my MacBook from the Apple Store today, booted it up, and as soon as I clicked on the Airport icon to turn it on, my computer froze with the instructions to shut down my computer in 4 languages. I shut down, booted up, and as soon as it started loading the operating system, it gave me the same fatal error message. Fix Hold down the Alt/Option key while booting up to get into Boot Camp. Startup Windows, then restart the computer and it's as good as new! But Parallels is still slow. What's a good amount of memory to dedicate to Windows XP under Parallels?

item.title: About TechGlobber
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Jotting down notes on solutions I couldn't find on Google. Also trying to write on a biblical perspective of technology...fairly unsuccessful so far. You can also read my blog at dtjm.tumblr.com

item.title: Apple Keynote and YouTube
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Looks like you can send Keynote presentations directly to YouTube. Could be a great convenience for sharing presentations. UPDATE Actually, when you export to YouTube, Keynote doesn't include any transitions...too bad. Looks like Flash export is the way to go for now.

item.title: What does the Bible say about technology?
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: I'm starting to dig through the Bible for a greater understanding of technology. I'm around Genesis 10 and it has already been pretty exciting. If you want to follow along, you can see the verses that I have noted: my technology verses at eBible.com On the web I found only 1 substantial piece of writing on this topic. You can find it here: Scripture on the use of technology. Let me know if you know any leading thought on the Biblical viewpoint on technology.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Can you answer your question?Im just looking.what do you think?
That's, hilarious. In a thousand years from now man could not create a machine to surpass the infinite complexities of the human mind.

All of sudden the last 200 years,which is such a flash in time compared to human life on earth.Why now do we have great techonology?We may only use 10% of our brain , even the most intelligent person.What a day it will be when God gives us 100%.What shame we will feel.I dont know why techonology exploded.I do know it is a divine plan.Bring gods children into the light & beat down the sickness of pride.(satan) Forgiveness (Jesus)

If anyone still monitors this. For you to really see how much God's word speaks of technology. We would have to know simple definitions. The bible says alot on this matter of technology. So if I were to swing to the other end of the scripture, say Revelation, where the woman rides the beast. Ok. Our definitions have not changed just what we call things. God's definitions have not changed. He's the Word. Just a thought to think about. Could that woman be a Motherboard (like in a computer). As I keep a close watch. Her popularity has run wild though out the world right under people's noses. She is very powerful. So much so the general public has no idea. Take the 3 fastest computers in the world. One's name is Legion. Another's ones name is the meaning of 'they move in smoke and mirrors', Cloud.
I know I sound crazy.
I would like to hear some more of your thoughts.
Kindly, Jason

Hi Jason, to be honest, yes you do sound crazy. What I am looking to do is flip it around and look at technology starting in Genesis. What kind of technology did Adam and Noah and Abraham use? Lets take a hundred steps back from high-tech and look at tech from its beginnings, be it weapons, vehicles, or processes for converting resources into tools and artifacts. How did characters in the Bible use and think about their technology? How does God think about it?

Technology will outsmart humans and create scientific breakthroughs. The intelligence of the collective machine mind will be far superior than that of humans, This will happen in the next 20 years. We will worship this new thing. We will need it. It will become a god. It will be amazing. This artificial intelligence will be the Antichrist.
A little later, this same technology will begin entering humans. It's inevitable, its evolution. It's what will happen. This is when the 2nd christ will come. The Christ must be of human.
Of course vice versa is a possibility.
I agree.
Hello I have just discovered your blog and I am very intriged. I look forward to reading what else you write about techonology and the Bible.

item.title: TechCrunch forces Picasa leak out of Google employee at MacWorld
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Michael Arrington of TechCrunch forces an unsuspecting Google rep at MacWorld to leak word of Picasa currently in development for OS X.Finally! I have been waiting for Picasa to come to the Mac. I am tired of iPhoto (except for the printed books feature, that is pretty cool).  Google Developing Mac Version Of Picasa, Due To Be Released This Year (TechCrunch)

item.title: Installing yum / subversion on Media Temple (dv), Feb 2008
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
Edit 3/12/2008: According to John's comment, you can do all this by installing the Developer Tools in your Media Temple Account Center. All you have to do after installing the developer tools is install the yum package itself (the last rpm command below) Edit 10/15/2008: Updated the URL for the yum RPM. Thanks Jordan. http://kb.mediatemple.net/article.php?id=807   
I just signed up for Media Temple (dv) server and was trying to get subversion installed. I couldn't find any up-to-date instructions so here are some in case you need:
  1. Get root access (Submit a support ticket and ask for root access. They will send you a password. Change the password to be safe.)
  2. Run these commands to install yum and its dependencies:
    rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/python-elementtree-1.2.6-5.i386.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/python-sqlite-1.1.7-1.2.1.i386.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/rpm-python-4.4.2-47.el5.i386.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/m2crypto-0.16-6.el5.1.i386.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/python-urlgrabber-3.1.0-2.noarch.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/yum-metadata-parser-1.0-8.fc6.i386.rpm rpm -Uvh http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/yum-3.2.8-9.el5.centos.1.noarch.rpm    
  3. Finally, to install subversion:
    yum install subversion   

Links

media temple dv install yum and media temple dv simpler svn install | hi my name is sid

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think it depends on which version of the dv you have as to whether or not Subversion is installed as part of the Developer Tools installation. I know it's there for dv 3.5. Best to check beforehand.

Just install the Developer's Tools from the Account Center. You used to have to request it but It has everything you need.
http://kb.mediatemple.net/article.php?id=807
Thanks for the info.

hey, i've been trying to install yum/nano and subversion on my mt server for the past couple of hours. i came across your site, and your instructions worked immediately. thank you very much.
!
Why there's no yum by default I will never know, but glad you posted this info! Thanks!
The dependencies have all been moved. Does anyone have the latest links?
I updated the mirrors and added a note that you just have to install the yum RPM package if you have the Developer Tools installed (according to my most recent (dv) experience)
The latest RPM for yum is at - http://mirror.centos.org/centos/5/os/i386/CentOS/yum-3.2.8-9.el5.centos.1.noarch.rpm
We wrote a similar article for the DV 3.5 servers, enjoy : http://www.debuggeddesigns.com/blog/view/how-to-setup-a-subversion-svn-repo-on-a-media-temple-dv-3.5-server

item.title: Extra System Info on the OS X Login Screen (Leopard)
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Here's a cool trick I just found by accident:  See under "Mac OS X" where it says the name of your computer on the login screen? If you click on it you can get info about your IP address, whether you can log into network logins, and other cool info. What will they think of next...

item.title: Time Machine Client Backups on Leopard Server
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: One of the best things about my job is that my company often buys the newest and best things for me to work with. One of the most recent purchases we've made is an Apple Xserve running Leopard Server. One of the reasons I was looking forward to getting my hands on this machine was so I could run Time Machine Backups onto it. Here are two big issues I've run into so far: 1. Users whose home directories live on the server can't use Time Machine to access their backups  Since the files live on the server, you have to log into the server to enter the Time Machine outer space interface. My solution to this right now is to create Mobile Accounts for users on their primary machines. 2.  I got the message "No Mac OS X System Backups Found" when attempting a full restore While trying to do a test Restore from Time Machine Backup from the OS X Installation Disc, I found that none of the image files had any backups listed. My solution to this was to go back into Time Machine Preferences and remove the "System" folder from my excluded backup locations, which seemed to do the trick.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It appears that this cannot be done using Server Admin and Workgroup Manager, but it may be possible using edquota (which I have never used, but saw something on it here) Workgroup Manager has a place to set disk quotas for a user, but I think that is only for the home directory. Server Admin has a place to turn on quotas (in the File Sharing tab), but you can't control the quotas from there. So I can turn on quotas for my Time Machine disk but I cannot change them in Server Admin.
When you have clients back up to the Leopard Server, are you able to set how much space they are allowed? For instance, userA can have 100GB of space, userB can have 250GB, etc?

item.title: Scheduled posts not appearing in Wordpress MU 1.3.3
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
We were having issues of scheduled posts not appearing at the scheduled time WordPress MU 1.3.3 We tried adding this snippet in wp-includes/cron.php: 
fflush($argyle);
fgets($argyle);
fclose($argyle);
Which was only half of the problem. What happened in our setup was that our machine that was hosting our WordPress installation could not access the site properly from the machine itself due to improper DNS settings So here's what I did:
  1. SSH into the machine which is hosting WordPress.
  2. Attempt to access the site using `lynx http://example.com/`. This showed me that I couldn't get to the site from the host itself, and therefore couldn't execute the wp-cron.php script.
  3. At this point I looked at the Apache configuration and realized that the virtual host for our WordPress installation was only listening on the public IP interface, not the localhost. The /etc/hosts was pointing example.com to the localhost interface, which made me see the default Apache web site when I tried to access http://example.com
  4. So I had to change /etc/hosts to make sure that example.com would resolve to the public IP interface.
The end!
References
  • http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/3742

item.title: Worst Technology Day Ever : Sep 10, 2008
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
[Edit: The Thumbs.db problem is a separate issue with a separate solution -- SXN, 9/13/08]
So today was pretty much the worst day ever in the history of setting up a mixed Windows and Mac environment. 
At work we have an Xserve (Early 2008) running Leopard Server 10.5.4, serving Windows and Mac clients.  The one particular user having problems runs Windows XP SP3 on Boot Camp 2.1 on a late 2007 iMac.

Problem 0:  Booting into Windows XP in Boot Camp

Okay so I came out of the shower this morning and Tivs tells me someone called from the office.  On the voicemail: "How do I boot back into Windows?"  Whoops.  I had set the startup disk of the iMac to the Mac partition and he couldn't get out.  

Solution 0

Easy enough.  Just reboot and hold Alt/Option when you hear the Mac startup sound until you see the startup disks show.  Then select the Windows partition.  
This foreshadowed the problems to come later in the day.

Problem 1: Losing network connection

I ride into the office a little early and within the first hour, the iMac had lost the network connection and thus lost connection to shared drives, causing file corruption on files that were being saved to the server.  Other symptoms include getting "Delayed write failed" messages from the Windows XP client.  Client machine couldn't ping any other hosts on the network, but could ping itself on localhost and local network IP interfaces (192.168.x.x)

Solution 1:  Workaround by restarting

I've been able to temporarily fix the issue by restarting the machine, but this is not a good long term fix.

Problem 2: User can save but not delete file on Samba share

We have several different sharepoints served through Samba, managed through Server Admin.  User had difficulty with one of the sharepoints.  He was able to save a file to the share, but thereafter was unable to delete or otherwise modify the file.  Upon further investigation (using `gpresult` to get the domain info on the user), I found that the user is missing some groups of which he is a member.  The first thing I did was try to change permissions on the sharepoint to give permissions to one of the groups that did show up in gpresult.  No dice.  Second thing was to delete the user from Open Directory and re-add him.  Nothing.  

Solution 2: "acl check permissions = no"

Finally, I found a thread on AFP548 which had the solution.  Apparently the Samba implementation in Leopard Server is screwed up, so I had to add "acl check permissions = no" to the [global] section of /private/etc/smb.conf.

Problem 3: User profile not saving Thumbs.db and Quickbooks 2006 QBW files

Okay, so I'm stoked that I got the sharepoint going. But I tell the user to work off of his desktop so that I can properly test the sharepoint later on. Desktop is safe. I soon prove this assumption wrong. The user scans an image and saves to a folder on his desktop, then copies a few Quickbooks files to his desktop and opens them up to work on them. He finishes that, then realizes he needs to install Quicken 2008. Everything's going smooth so far until the Quicken Installer requests a system restart. Two files fail to copy over to the roaming profile share on the server: the 2 Quickbooks QBW files that he had opened and closed.
Fine, I think. Just log back in, and the files will still be on the local profile. Wrong! They were deleted! WTF?! Now the user can't log into his profile due to the fact that the user can't copy all the files back from the profile on the server. So a couple hours later, here's what I found:  >
  1. If you open and close a Quickbooks file, the file will become read-only in Windows.
  2. If a user owns a folder on the Server, he cannot copy a read-only file into that folder even if he is the owner and has POSIX permissions 700
  3. Also, if a user has those permissions on a Quickbooks file on the server, the file will not open properly in Quickbooks.
I tested this by opening and closing a Quickbooks file, then checking the file properties. It was read-only. Then I tried dragging and dropping that QBW file into the user's Desktop folder (\\xserve\profiles\user\Desktop). The progress meter goes all the way across, then I get an error. If I uncheck the read-only checkbox, the copy succeeds.

Solution 3: Full-Control Access Control Entry (ACE)

So what eventually worked was giving the user a Full-Control ACE, and propogating it down to all child folders and files. This allowed read-only files to be properly copied back to the user's Windows profile on the server.

Notes:

Another thing I did was turn off oplocks on the share that holds our Quickbooks files because I saw it on this page, and apparently they shouldn't be used for shares which are available by AFP and SMB.
I had to write this out for my own catharsis.  If this helps anyone else, the day was not spent in vain!

item.title: Thumbs.db, Windows XP, and Leopard Server
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
So, it seems that with a default installation of Leopard Server and a Windows XP client, you will be able to write a Thumbs.db file to a Samba share, but not read it. Seems silly enough but here is what fixed it for me:
  1. Edit /private/etc/smb.conf and replace this line:
    vfs objects = darwinacl, darwin_streams
    with this: (removing ", darwin_streams")
    vfs objects = darwinacl
  2. Then change these lines:
    ; The darwin_streams module gives us named streams support. stream support = yes ea support = yes
    to this:
    ; The darwin_streams module gives us named streams support. stream support = no ea support = no

References

  • Samba shares and HFS extended attributes - MacOSX.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This worked for me but for a different/similar problem. Users with roaming profiles were getting errors when logging out. When the copy process would hit certain *.url files stored in the favorites folder it would fail. No strange permissions or anything, it would say it was unable to update the given file because of network or permission problems. There would be a long space after that followed by a detail, saying there wasn't enough space on the disk to write the file. (multiple Gigs were in fact available).

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Worst Technology Day Ever : Sep 10, 2008 « TechGlobber
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Technology Day Ever : Sep 10, 2008 [Edit: The Thumbs.db problem is a separate issue with a separate solution -- SXN, 9/13/08] So today was pretty much the worst day ever in the history of setting up a mixed [...]

item.title: Genesis 4:17-22 — Cities, tents, music, and metalwork
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
This passage is packed with new industry:
Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and bore Enoch. When he built a city, he called the name of the city after the name of his son, Enoch. To Enoch was born Irad, and Irad fathered Mehujael, and Mehujael fathered Methushael, and Methushael fathered Lamech ... Adah bore Jabal; he was the father of those who dwell in tents and have livestock. His brother's name was Jubal; he was the father of all those who play the lyre and pipe.  Zillah also bore Tubal-cain; he was the forger of all instruments of bronze and iron.
First of all, you now have cities, which at the most basic level are probably a collection of tents.  Having tents implies a knowledge of making fabrics or perhaps using branches and leaves to create a basic building structure.  The mention of the lyre and pipe implies that they know the process of creating such instruments, which likely required fine wood and metalwork skills.  Finally, they introduced bronze and iron industrial processes. I'm seeing pattern here of how technology fits into Scripture: it just happens!  There's no technical backgrounding, it's just there, as though it were always there.  It's nothing new.

item.title: Printing to the Konica Minolta Di3010 from OS X 10.5 Leopard with Job Accounting
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_87" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Konica Minolta Di3010"][/caption] Our office uses an old Konica Minolta Di3010 as our black & white copy/print/scan workhorse.  But when we switched over to Mac workstations, I found that the available drivers just didn't work because it didn't handle the job accounting codes properly (aka account tracking, job tracking, job management). Anyone I talked to at Konica Minolta said that the machine was too old and wouldn't work with the OS X 10.5, so we thought we would have to go out and drop 10 G's on a new Mac-compatible machine.  Finally I got a hold of a Konica Minolta "Application Specialist" who said he would look into it and mentioned that I would need to input my Account Tracking code into the drive.  I got a little impatient, and after investigating some packet dumps from Windows, I figured out how to hack the PPD driver file. Using Wireshark, I found that the PC driver was sending a line like this, which the Mac driver was not sending:
@PJL SET GROUPCODE="1234"
To make the Mac driver set the proper groupcode, I copied the KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS.ppd file to KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS HACK.ppd and added something like this inside of the "InstallableOptions" block after the set of lines regarding "Option11":
*OpenUI *Option12/Job Management: PickOne *OrderDependency: 20.0 AnySetup *Option12 *DefaultOption12: DEPT1 *Option12 DEPT1/Department One: "%@PJL SET GROUPCODE=<22>1234<22><0A>" *Option12 DEPT2/Department Two: "%@PJL SET GROUPCODE=<22>2345<22><0A>" *Option12 DEPT3/Department Three: "%@PJL SET GROUPCODE=<22>3456<22><0A>" *CloseUI: *Option12
This block of code sets 3 different accounts with pre-defined accounting codes, which you will be able to choose when you install the printer (or when you go to the printer's Options page). In this process, I learned that each line has to start with "%" even though that character doesn't get printed.  Hex values in <>'s get printed as their ASCII characters, which is how I managed to get quotes around the GROUPCODE value.  The <0A> at the end is just an ASCII newline character. In the header section, I modified these lines to identify the new PPD file:
*PCFileName: "KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS HACK.ppd" *ModelName: "KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS HACK" *ShortNickName: "KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS HACK" *NickName: "KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS HACK"
I also added this line underneath *Nickname so that the printer icon would show the actual unit, not a generic printer icon:
*APPrinterIconPath: "/Library/Printers/KonicaMinolta/Icons/Di3010.icns"
To use this, you'll need to put the ICNS file in the location specified above.  Let me know if you want my ICNS file, and I'll e-mail it to you. Take your hacked PPD file and put it into /Library/Printers/PPDs/Contents/Resources/. Now, when you add a printer, the driver should show up in the OS X printer driver list as Konica Minolta Di3010 PS HACK, or whatever you set the name to be. Another modification I made to the PPD file was set the defaults to match the hardware configuration of our unit, so I set:
*DefaultOption5: True *DefaultOption7: FN117
It's been working great so far as an LPD printer.  I've successfully tested duplex printing and landscape printing as well. I hope this helps someone out there and saves you money!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It comes in the Konica driver package that comes with the copier. It's the version for OS X 10.4. You should be able to download it here: http://onyxftp.mykonicaminolta.com/download/SearchResults.aspx?productid=324&filetypeid=0
I'm having the same problem, but I can't locate the KONICA MINOLTA Di3010 PS.ppd file

item.title: Adjix security bug
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: Yesterday I found a pretty serious security flaw in the Adjix software. They wrote about it here: http://blog.adjix.com/2009/02/security-hole-found-fixed-and-deployed.html

item.title: Link: fantastic site on technology & humanity
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
I came across an excellent blog this weekend on the influence of technology on humanity.  It's exactly what I was looking for, but had a lot of trouble finding.  Most of faith + technology stuff I had seen before was about how to use technology in ministry.  This site seems to tackle the question of how technology affects life as a whole, but from a biblical worldview.

Don't Eat The Fruit

item.title: How to convert EMF files on Mac OS X using Microsoft Word
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded:
Here's a little trick for converting EMF (Enhanced Metafile) images. You'll need Microsoft Word:
  1. Drag the image into a blank Word document
  2. Right-click on the image
  3. Click Save as picture...
That will let you save it as a PNG, PDF, JPEG, BMP, or GIF. This worked on Word 2008 for Mac and OS X 10.5.7.

item.content:encoded: Go to Talon and grab the bookmarklet in the upper-right corner of the page.

item.excerpt:encoded: BROKEN IN 1.8: Passing String value to Progress Bar

item.title: jQuery UI Progress Bar Widget - upgrading to 1.8
item.dc:creator: Sam
item.content:encoded: If you are upgrading your jQuery UI build from 1.7 to 1.8 and you are using the Progress Bar widget, AND your progress bars break after the upgrade, make sure you are passing Number values, not String values to the "value" option of the Progress Bar plugin. [caption id="attachment_125" align="alignleft" width="113" caption="BROKEN IN 1.8: Passing String value to Progress Bar"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_124" align="alignleft" width="109" caption="WORKS in 1.8: Passing Number values"][/caption]
